ghostPost.title: Getting Started with Business Hours
ghostPost.html:
Video Overview

We used Business Hours in our video about time-based workflow rules to make sure that we were creating a counter that only counted business hours, not weekends and holidays. Check out that post here for more information!

Here’s the anonymous Apex code we executed to perform a test of our business hours. Make sure to replace “Eastern US” with whatever you named your business hours.

BusinessHours bh = [SELECT Id, Name FROM BusinessHours WHERE Name = 'Eastern US'];

// 8 Hours * 60 Seconds * 60 Minutes * 1000 Milliseconds
Datetime eightBusinessHours = BusinessHours.add(bh.Id, Datetime.now(), 8*60*60*1000);

// A much simpler function!!
Datetime eightCalendarHours = Datetime.now().addHours(8);


System.debug('8 BUSINESS HOURS FROM NOW IS: ' + eightBusinessHours);
System.debug('8 CALENDAR HOURS FROM NOW IS: ' + eightCalendarHours);

And here’s the query itself, separated. You can use the “Query Editor” tab within the Developer Console to execute and see the results of queries, or you can use Workbench. I prefer workbench because it gives you a nice interface to build a query, but for simple things like the following, the Developer Console is more than enough.

SELECT Id, Name FROM BusinessHours

SELECT Id, Name FROM BusinessHours WHERE Name = 'Eastern US'

Thanks for watching!
